number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
												This is a fun, turn based Strategy RPG focusing on controlling an Empire and the Heroes that you recruit. (CATEGORY) "Poor/Sub-Par/Average/Great/Superb" 1-5/5 - Description(OVERALL)- My personal rating for this game is 85%. My average rating for this is 71% (3.5/5)(GAMEPLAY)  "Superb" 5/5 - Battles are turn based tactics using a grid system, similar to games like Final Fantasy Tactics, Poxnora, Disgaea, Ogre Tactics, etc. Each turn you aquire resources depending on what mines/ect you've captured, and can spend those resources to upgrade your town(s). Your Heroes gain levels, and new abilities which are both passive, affecting the Army of Monsters you recruit at your town, or directly doing damage or providing some various effects (slowing down enemies, speeding yours up, summoning monsters to fight for you, etc). You end up fighting Neutral monsters that are stationary on the map, usually blocking your path as your armies are too weak (at first). Armies are formed from Monsters/Units that you pay to recruit (with gold) at your town/village. Each unit bought will represent a "Stack" of units. You have around 10 slots to have different types of creatures in your army, and you can have as many "Stacks" as you can afford / create to build up your forces. There are a huge variety of ways to play this game, all of which are really fun. Many elements of this game are comparable to a 4X game. (STORY)  "Sub-Par" 2/5 -There is a storymode to this game, and infact it is one of the best ways to get strong gear for your Hero. Gear aquired during those missions (and some other ways) allow you to make your Hero stronger, earlier, in any form of gameplay. The story isn't insanely good, but I found it to be very well done as far as being creative. Depending on what DLC you buy changes how much story you can access. This is one of the greater faults for the game. The story itself is something I like, however limiting it by DLC is not something that I favor. (Note, without some of the DLC (IE you bought Shades of Darkness, not the original) you will get a lot less content, which is why this is a 2/5)(GRAPHICS)  "Average" 3/5 - The graphics are quite good, but not amazing. There is enough going on in the world that it can draw you in, as a fantasy world. There are all sorts of odd buildings, and interactable objects. Exploration is one fun factor in the game (as there is Fog of War) and the graphics help tie in the feeling of exploration. Seeing the units in 3D during battle is always nice, and fun to watch (though if you have a slow-walking unit, try speeding up how fast your units move)(SOUND)  "Great" 4/5 - At first I was going to rate this a 3/5, but I realized that several of the songs in this game had gotten stuck in my head. Remembering that, it was a lot easier to rate this a 4/5. The Gameplay was addictive, and so is the music. Although it isn't anything over-the-top, or mind-blowing, it is still a fitting sound track. (ONLINE)  "Sub-Par" 2/5 - The games worst issue, by far. MMH VI has to be connected to the internet at all times to play the game. DRM-Stuff. This is a huge deterrant for most people, and thus have rated this section quite low. However on the flip side it has a great single player mode (which you still need to be connected to the internet to play) which you can setup your own matches against the NPC's and either destroy them, or be destroyed! It is a lot of fun learning tactics for certain maps, and for certain factions. (RE-PLAYABILITY) "Superb" 5/5 - This game is truly addictive. While I only have 40 hours in the game right now, it is because I haven't been able to re-install it and to get it working (with an issue others have had, a black screen) I haven't tried re-downloading and installing since I tried last. The game has a great sense of addictiveness to it. You earn new equipment to use on your Hero. Your hero gains new levels, and you can re-do it every match. You can play all sorts of different tactics, take your time or not, and generally, do what you want. (COST) "Average" 4/5 - This game costs either 30$ USD or 20$ USD (Depending on if you get the base game or Shades of Darkness) My review is based on Shades of Darkness. At 20$ USD, this is a steal of a game, as long as you don't mind staying connected to the internet. (OVERALL)- My personal rating for this game would likely be a 4/5. My average rating for this was a 3.5/5 or a 70%.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 17, 2014
												I've mixed feelings about this game. Ever since spending countless hours playing Heroes of Might and Magic III and it's expansions/mods years ago,  I've been a fan. I love a good turn-based tactical combat based game. In fact, it may be my favorite genre. A strong strategy of collecting resources, helpful items and building powerful kingdoms backed by a solid story, good character dialogue, with outstanding art and soundtrack all mixed together, it's my opinion there is no topping this genre of game. Might and Magic: Heroes VI though falls short of legendary status for many reasons. Many avenues of this series have been simplified such as the resources, additions like the caravan options from HoMM IV and NPC monsters on the map being able to attack you during their turn if you are too close are missing. The story is nothing that held my interest and the dialogue happening in the pop-up screens was pretty horrible in many instances, and the in-game cutscene graphics are pretty generic. I did enjoy the map art and the soundtrack was okay. The gameplay is decent, though at many times not challenging. I had to crank up the difficulty to hard for any real strategy. On normal it can be difficult in the first few levels, but once you amass some powers/items/armies it's pretty much a steamroll. I played through 3 of the campaigns and towards the end of the 3rd I was getting bored and just selecting auto-battle and having minimal to no losses. I did like the inclusion of dynasty weapons, dynasty traits and having to open further slots and options by playing more and earning the achievement points. Again, there wasn't much of a challenge to the achievements other than just playing long enough to rack up enough kills/battles won without losses/ etc. Uplay is another barrier. Online activation to continue your game, if you do need/have to be offline you have to play a game started in offline mode.  I don't like to open my steam purchased game in two menus. Not a deal breaker for me, but annoying and unnecessary.I doubt I'll go back and play another full campaign. Perhaps, a random map here and there. Overall, it's just okay. Nothing spectatular that a turn-based strategy lover must have, but a worthy buy if you come across for cheap.

content:
er 26, 2013
												If you are a fan of turn-based tactical games, then this is a great entry in the genre, and even a better entry in the M&M series than the others to date.  M&M: Heroes 5 managed to hold my interest for somewhere around 15 to 20 hours, while I have enjoyed this one for almost 250 hours at the time of writing this review.The game does become fairly repetitive after a while, but its repetitiveness was not enough to put me off the game.  I typically get somewhere between 30 minutes to 5 hours out of a game, while games that I particularly enjoy might go as high as 60 or 70.  There is usually only one games each year that will get me to put in more than 40 hours, let alone the time I have invested into this game.I do find the UPlay dependence a bit obnoxious, as it sometimes takes up to a minute to get past the "Checking for UPlay Updates" screen (this on the latest system w/ SSD, 32gb RAM, 100mbit internet connection, etc.)  I was also disconnected partway through a major battle due to UPlay going offline.  I found this part to be inexcusable - it had a connection, let it reassert itself when it can but don't kick me out of the game!

content:
1, 2014
												If you've played Heroes III, IV, or V, know that this game is better. Yes, even better than Heroes III. Balace is well done, each faction has abilities that make them distinct and fun to play, and the combat strategy becomes more customizable thanks to the skill trees that you can fill as your heroes level up. Campaigns are extensive - each takes about 20 hours to complete (I've only made it through two), and there are about five in the base game.The only probem with this game lies with Ubisoft's "Conflux," an always-on social application that you must be connected to in order to play. It isn't intrusive, but it does mean that you need an internet connection to play, and if your internet cuts out, the game boots you out - even if you're in the middle of a 15 minute castle seige - and you have to reload the last save when you reconnect. It's a ♥♥♥♥♥, but it's ony a problem if you have unreliable internet.

This is true even on the easiest settings.The tutorial campaigns are misleading, as the game seems balanced (if not a tad easy). Do not expect this to last long.Either take the time to download a cheat trainer (as there are no simple cheat codes) and cheat harder than the AI.... or just don't play.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 10, 2014
												A fun, intuitive and challenging game, Heroes VI is my favourite in the series. The graphics are BEAUTIFUL and the real-time battle models look astounding. Battles are a mix of complicated turn-based, chess-like gameplay, with interesting, game-changing abilities. The maps are fun to explore and are filled with treasure and plenty of monsters to fight. One thing worth noting is the difficulty of the campaigns. The AI are smart and aggresive. So if you are are a fan of being  able to say, "I've finished this game, good luck at doing it yourself", then you will really enjoy this. Heroes VI is also great fun to play against friends. It features a hot-seat gametype which can be tedious if you don't like waiting for your slow friend, though the AI in Custom Game will be a worthy, oppenent in an actual player's stead. So, if you are a fan of expansive, challenging strategy games or enjoyed the other games in this series, this should be an memorable experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 1, 2014
												I've grown up playing Heroes, and I have to say - this version is stupendous.  They brought back classic elements that were stripped from players in IV and V, and overhauled the interface.  The community HUB is a nice touch, giving players access to other players who are also playing, the cross hero artifacts are a nice bonus too, allowing me to play with any hero I want and still increase their strength.  The more I play, the stronger I'll get!The animations have been improved from V, and the voice acting is a lot better too!The load times are much improved also, and the time waiting for enemies to finish their turns is faster now too.One downside is U-Play.  Not very happy that I need to load U-Play to play the game when I bought it and play it through steam.  Besides that, it's a worthwhile game to play!

												I'm writting this after playing foor 10hrs straight. I played all of the Heroes games ever made (including the expansions) and I can safely state that this is now absolutely my new favourite one.Some people complain that the game is buggy, but I've yet to encounter anything like that. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 23, 2014
												A good game in a great franchise ruined by a bad company.  You can see that I have a lot of hours logged into this game.  What you don't see is that a tremendous number of those hours are idle; I simply refused to log out because I thoroughly distrusted uPlay to the point of not believing I would ever be able to log back in if I logged out.  Previous experience justified that fear.  Subsequent experience validated it.  I finally had to reboot my machine.  Once again, I cannot get into the game because of uPlay.  The latest "update" to uPlay upgraded my experience by once again denying it to me entirely--as in, where I once could log on, I no longer can.When I was in the game, I was able to get through the first campaign and part of the second.  The game is a respectable member of the HOMM franchise but nothing truly revolutionary (the primary new element, dynasty weapons, is a good concept and I hope that it appears again, but it isn't exactly series-defining), and there are definite power balance issues among the factions.  Fortunately for beginners, you start playing the easiest (most powerful) faction (Necropolis), but the balance issues could be serious in multiplayer with random factions.The bottom line is simple: Not only do I not recommend this game for as long as uPlay exists, but I personally will not buy another Ubisoft title of any kind until they abandon or dramatically reform that system.  There are many excellent publishers out there that treat their customers with more respect, or failing that, if they force you to use proprietary portals, at least they function.

Not very happy that I need to load U-Play to play the game when I bought it and play it through steam.  Besides that, it's a worthwhile game to play!

content:
y 10, 2014
												A fun, intuitive and challenging game, Heroes VI is my favourite in the series. The graphics are BEAUTIFUL and the real-time battle models look astounding. Battles are a mix of complicated turn-based, chess-like gameplay, with interesting, game-changing abilities. The maps are fun to explore and are filled with treasure and plenty of monsters to fight. One thing worth noting is the difficulty of the campaigns. The AI are smart and aggresive. So if you are are a fan of being  able to say, "I've finished this game, good luck at doing it yourself", then you will really enjoy this. Heroes VI is also great fun to play against friends. It features a hot-seat gametype which can be tedious if you don't like waiting for your slow friend, though the AI in Custom Game will be a worthy, oppenent in an actual player's stead. So, if you are a fan of expansive, challenging strategy games or enjoyed the other games in this series, this should be an memorable experience.

content:
y 3, 2014
												First of all I would like to say I am disappointed and suprised about the excessive negative reviews. Luckily, I was able to purchase the complete edition of this game, I believe it is the Base + 3 expansions for just over $10. That is a lot of game for a small price tag, so I was willing to deal with any issues I found.Currently, I have played over 10 hours into this game and I have to say that I don't see what everyone else is belly-aching about. I see a lot of crying on the reviews, but in game I see nothing but positive.I run a PC with Windows 7 Professional, AMD 8-core processor, Geforce 545GT, so my rig is okay, but definitely not the best. I have not crashed once, no freezing, no glithes, no bugs, literally no issues.This game is visually stunning, challenging and engaging, very detailed, and FUN! You can really tell that some talented people put a ton of time into this game and it's mechanics. It's a lot like Warcraft 3, but it's very different too; you don't really fight directly with your hero, just your army and there is a vast variety of spells, abilities, weapons, gear and units to build and choose from, you also control and build a city.Now, don't get me wrong, this game isn't perfect, and there is some room for improvement. For instance, there is a lot to learn and the tutorial is fairly long and drags on a bit and if you take too much time building an army, you may find yourself unable to defeat the objectives due to overwhelming forces.This is just my two cents, but I really feel this game was given a bad rep by some people who didn't give it a fair chance or judged it based on things the game wasn't at fault for. Hope this helps.

content:
, 2015
												The AI cheats and is terribly unbalanced. The AI's armies will always be 2x-3x or more the size of your's, will be hitting for max (or closer to max) damage more often, and will whittle down your stack sizes faster than you ever can ever hope to. This is true even on the easiest settings.The tutorial campaigns are misleading, as the game seems balanced (if not a tad easy). Do not expect this to last long.Either take the time to download a cheat trainer (as there are no simple cheat codes) and cheat harder than the AI.... or just don't play.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2015
												Graphics are pretty cool for a turn-based strategy, especially compared to the previous Heroes games. But in terms of gameplay everything is simplified - lower number of resources, common army pool, easy town portal for every hero etc. There are some good ideas like forts / zones of control, and even town conversion could be a pretty good idea if implemented in a different way (e.g. took several days, cost much more, and was not allowed for every castle in the game). But general impression is still not very good, considering that there are still some bugs in the game (4 years after release!), and that UPlay client is inconvenient and buggy (crashed on start immediately after installation, and kept crashing until I fixed some issues with file permissions - it is clearly written in a very bad style if it tries to write something into his own Program Files directory). But, if you're a fan of Heroes series - you should definitely try it out. It was still a lot of fun to me, especially playing new Dungeon faction - their creatures are very cool.

content:
r 27, 2015
												Though I've not played anywhere NEAR as much as the time logged indicates, I will say - I have tried to like this game.  But, it's AI basically amounts to building armies at 3-4 times your rate.  Even on easy.  They aren't brilliant (I watched the last orc attacking my city, who was alrwady INSIDE the city, turn and attack the wall leading in).  They're just overtly numerous.  2-3 heroes with armies bigger than your main army can muster (again, even on easy for the Haven campaign) will be constantly on the attack, and in your zone.It's sad, because I've come back TRYING to like this game.  I'm not a Heroes III fanatic, in fact I didn't even play it.  But though I DID like Heroes V, I didn't judge this against it.  I'm merely saying an unfinished game at release was obviously glossed over as 'completed' by simply letting an ignorant AI outnumber you to your death.  I don't recommend.

Recaptures the feel and subtle complexity of the original Heroes game while adding larger tactical combat maps, additional inventory options, zones of control and swapable buildings in the cities.  The biggest weakness is the game's interface which can seem a bit awkward.  Overall, I'd recommend it, especially on sale.  Beware, however, as the game uses (and requires the installation of) Uplay, Ubisoft's DRM system.

content:
ber 18, 2014
												Might & Magic: Heroes VI is a bit of a mixed bag in my honest opinion. Right off the bat I’ll say that, overall, the game is decent with enough content and unlockables to keep you occupied for a while. The various factions each focus on their own unique theme and due to this they also have different units to go along with it as well as heroes that can be adapted to your playstyle with the use of skill trees and reputation. This works just as well in the different campaigns where the reputation you choose for the main character will actually influence the story potentially giving you two different endings for each one. As good as this may sound the game isn't without issues that potentially ruin the whole experience (at least it did for me).Firstly it's worth mentioning that the game uses Uplay (a platform made by Ubisoft) as opposed to Steam meaning you have to register the game on a Uplay account as well. This was more of a slightly annoyance rather than a problem so I won't get too much into this point but I have heard that this has caused problems that seem to involve Uplay not accepting activation keys provided by Steam.The main problem I have with this game is the way the multiplayer was handled and how disappointing it was. I bought this game to play with a good friend but in our first game we quickly discovered that you couldn't watch battles being fought by other players (including allies). This means that every battle that your friend will take part in is another 5 minutes of having to sit there and watch the map as nothing happens (unless you both make use of the quick fight feature which I would recommend doing). This also means that you're forced to miss out on any significant battles between your friend and enemy heroes which may decide the outcome of a match. What? You actually wanted to see these two mighty armies clash? You wanted to laugh at your friend as he makes a bad move and gets a stack of his units killed or even see what his faction plays like? Too bad. You can't.The only way I can really recommend this game is as a single-player game which it seems to do well enough but as a multiplayer game it just feels like most matches (under normal circumstances) take longer than they should and even when you do finish it you look back and realise that the experience could have been much better. Regardless, if this game ever goes on sale and you are a fan of turn-based strategy games then I would still recommend it even if it's just for the campaign and the occasional skirmish against AI.

												My only complaint is that all the maps are pregenerated - you can't generate random maps.The gameplay is a balancing act of economy building which is pretty subtle.  I lost an easy map 3 times before figuring out a way that worked (and even then I might have just gotten lucky).The music is excellent - which means a lot coming from me.  I'm very picky about music.Also the artwork is very well done and nice to come back to.This is not a TBS like Civilization, because the maps are very linear and sort of contrived.  You can't build as many cities as you want - everything is fixed on the maps.  But it's still FUN and really artful and some of the artwork is so good I'll forget about the game for months and then an image pops up in my head and I want to play this again.The tactics are interesting because some units take up more than a single square - like 2x2.  In those cases you can set up shielding formations to protect your most important units, maybe other cases too.Yes buy it.Also... as far as Uplay goes... yes it's a pain in the ♥♥♥, but so is Steam.  It's just another platform and this is just the way developers do marketting.  I don't care.  I can still get to the gameplay and I enjoy it once I get there.  That's all I care about.  Uplay IS a pain in the ♥♥♥ though - they want to suggest 2-step verification.  Guess what Uplay - this is a ♥♥♥♥ing game not a bank account I don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about your stupide 2-step verification ideas!

content:
er 8, 2015
												I had decided to withhold a review of this game because I didn't want to undermine the release of HOMM7 but since metacritic scores say HOMM7 is crap anyways I will go ahead and review.As far as pro and cons go it is easier to criticize than to praise. I will try and cover good points first.- This game is a huge time sink. Games that are huge time sinks are good at what they do.- The maps are well decorated.- The combat for haven town has some depth.- The AI can play a good game of cat and mouse on the world map for forts and places equidistant between two forts or a fort and a town or two towns.- The faction ability adds some depth to combat.- Some hero spells can make combat more strategic.- Movement speed of units on the map and in combat can be sped up in options.As for the cons:Simply put the game is over streamlined. Because of this it becomes very lather rinse repeat.- No matter what you play your first two hero skills are likely going to be +20% gold and +3 movement since a critical part of the game is amassing resources and building your city up quickly. The difference between doing this and not doing this is quite large. It can be the difference between a steamroller and attrition.- The hero customization is very MMOey. It doesn't really provide any kind of uniqueness to your heroes. If you're a warrior class you will likely use the same skill set every game with mass stone skin and maybe some other spell thrown in. If you are a mage there is somewhat more customization but it really comes down to a combination of summons to block ranged units, some kind of healing spell, maybe nukes but nukes tend to fade away in effectiveness as armies get bigger, and again mass stoneskin.- The game map is very streamlined. You can usually get away with a vanguard hero and a scout. Mines are only relevant as far as clearing them is concerned. Everything revolves around forts and towns. And thus the game is about the +20% gold and +3 movement at the start and building up as quickly as possible and then vanguard hero sniping. You can plunder and sabatoge mines but it is usually out of the way and at best forces a player to gate. At worst they simply step out of their town and kill your hero.- Aside from the haven town where vestals become important you can do most of the game with quick combat turned on. As a result most of the critical gameplay happens on the world map which is over streamlined with towns and forts and revolves around vanguard hero sniping.The unit trees are quite linear. With only three resources unit build-up usually follows the same pattern. The only real curveball is deciding when to build your warpgate.Hero leveling is mostly irrelevant in the campaigns. You are either a level 15 hero or not a level 15 hero.Converting towns is another element that over streamlines the game. I don't see an option to turn it off in any menu so no mixed unit tactics.To conclude a very streamlined game that revolves around linear build-up and vanguard hero sniping with little hero uniqueness and few strategic goals on the world map. However it is a hefty timesink and simple can be fun.

content:
er 24, 2015
Probably the Best "Heroes" since HMM III.PreambleBeing a massive fan of HMMIII, and having played all the following games in the series (Except M&M: HVII) I would rather warmly recommend M&M:HVI.While the game was first plagued by game breaking issues courtesy of Ubisoft's dodgy DRM, numerous bugs, and a lack of Town screen which caused an uproar when the game first released, these problems were eventually addressed. I think a lot of the negative reviews date back to the olden days of 2011 In my infinite wisdom, I only bought the game a year or so after it released, and my experience was only slightly mired by the innate DRM and Conflux systems. I've not played all the DLC content available today for M&M:HVI, only Shades of Darkness (SoD), so this is the scope of this review.  The GoodThe campaigns are interesting overall, with some of them really shining as possibly the best campaigns  in the entire series. This is particularly true for the SoD extension which was thoroughly enjoyable in my opinion. I liked as well that the main heroes in campaigns are related to the other heroes by an overarching story frame, which - to boot - allows you to play the campaigns in pretty much any order. The game also includes the "Dynasty system" allowing you to unlock Heroes and additional bonuses that can then be used in multiplayer and other modes, as well as weapons and pets for your campaign Heroes.Last but not least, also included is a Karma system of sorts which, through your choices and actions, allows to you to gear your main Heroes towards super-good or mega-evil, thus gaining equally good or evil superpowers. This is a tiered system, which at first provides small but useful advantages, but by the time you reach the last scenario in a campaign will give your Hero some massive bonuses. This adds another level of customization to your heroes and provides some replay value for the campaigns. The profusion of ways in which your Heroes can be tweaked, upgraded and customized will give the min-maxers a great time. Graphics and audio are pretty good, though some of the voice acting can be a bit off-putting at times, but overall the presentation is pretty good. The gameplay, exploration, city management, kingdom building, hero development are all very enjoyable. The battle system while being very classic is also very enjoyable thanks to a clear interface, nice graphics and animations (which after a few hours you will certainly want to speed up !)The BadOn the downside, you have to bear with an "AI", which at times is so obviously scripted that it becomes a bit of an immersion breaker. (Hello Inferno campaign!). The Truly EvilAh! UBISOFT darling when will you understand that such heavy handed DRM only affects the people who actually purchase your games? We're not in 1990 anymore when everyone was burning "backup" copies of games and "lending" them to our friends! We have the internet and we have smarts! We can download in a few mere minutes DRM-free versions of your games and enjoy their content without your annoying, crippling, absurd and utterly pointless DRM!To the point, Uplay, the DRM, should really be called Udontplay, because frankly it can be pretty hard to get the game to start after installing it. Thankfully in most cases you will find the solution in this here forum or on the web.ConclusionLastly, once you are past the DRM Gates of Hell, Heroes VI, offers great gameplay and a huge amount of content to play through, even more so nowadays with all DLCs available. Overall, with 313 hours on my counter, I must say I have very much enjoyed Heroes VI + SoD, more so than any other since the days of HMMIII. (Excluding Heroes VII- which, in my still infinite wisdom, I will not buy before Ubi gets their game together so to speak.)

												I would like to give this game a good review, I really would seeing as the Might and Magic series is something I played many years ago and enjoyed however I just cannot here.The simple fact of the matter is Uplay is the worst thing to ever happen to gaming and has no place existing whatsoever. Despite buying this game through steam you will have to go through the Uplay platform in order to play it and Uplay is just not gaming, or anyone for that matter, friendly.I have barely been able to play this game to its fullest as Uplay HATES routers and trying to use any online functions connecting via a router will meet you with a brick wall "cannot connect to servers" message with staff members telling you to go through a lengthy and potentailly dangerous (if you have no idea what you're doing) process of port forwarding your router.The second reason I have barely been able to play the game is because the games response to a connection drop is the most insulting thing I have ever seen. I played a level for some time without saving and my router crashed, at which point I was kicked out of my game, sent to the main menu and to my horror found that my entire progress was deleted. I managed to recover this by playing the "offline" function but even the "offline" mode is created in such a way to PUNISH the player for daring to oppose using Uplay services as by playing offline you cannot access many functions of the game.Unless Uplay is removed and replaced with Steam servers or is fixed to actually work my only advice unless you use a direct internet connection or are routing savvy is to just avoid the game altogether and break out your old Might and Magic games which were created in a day when companies didn't hate gamers.

Is this a direct result of Console Peasents buying more PCs, or is the Master Race not as L33t as they assumed?What can I say though? Better than V in every way, with Blackhole getting very close to mirroring the original feel and mechanics that made this series great. Is this III or IV worthy? Hardly... number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
2016
												Do not buy this game.My PC is an i7, 3GHz, 24GB of ram and a GeForce 960 1GB video adapterPlaying on high graphics settings is not possible as I never get 30fps. Then I tried low graphics and I get 70fps, except every time I move my hero it goes down to 20fps.I am able to play games like Shadow of Mordor on full graphics without a glitch. How is that possible??The DRM is terrible, having to install UPlay and be always online is outrageous.Loading times are very long.Sometimes textures are missing from the game and I can see the checkered placeholder instead.I am a big fan of the Heroes franchise but what Ubisoft has done here is at best a wannabe that should be forgotten.The 20 hours I have on record are already too many for what this game deservesI would be ashamed of releasing anything like this as an indie/garage developer.On top of that it has been 5 years and every couple of years I come back to the game hoping for a patch that would make it playable. Instead they release and charge for 2 more expansions of the same crap.I guess I'm giving up. I'll uninstall it finally and will probably not buy the next one either, because to me this feels like a scam.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2015
												Very good game.Pros: 1) Nice graphics and beautiful environment 2) Engaging gameplay after a few hours of adaptation 3) Ability to convert cities of other fractions 4) Well made animation of units and spells (exept might hero basic attack) 5) New skill distribution system, which allows you to build your hero the exact way you want him 6) Interesting blood/tears reputation abilities  7) Dynasty weapons and perks 8) Music 9) Overall creature growth and hire - very usefulCons: 1) Cities. Awful cities as before as after the patch 2) Sometimes inappropriate units' voices 3) Somewhat lazy made storyline in main campaingsI recommend this game to every heroes series' fan (exept those who like thirds and thirds only) and to everyone who likes strategies. If you've played thirds' fourths and fifths at least try to give this game a chance. I too was very angry at developers at first for their innovations, but after a few days i understood that this game is good, despite all negative sides (Cities). Looking back now, i regret that i didn't bought this game before, when Blackhole studios (original developers) still existed.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												I just finished the HoMM V after playing it for the first time this weekend.And loved the game so much I bought the Hammers of Fate expansion as well as HoMM VI and also started playing HoMM Online as well.Way back in 2002 I had purchased what I believe was HoMM IV, my first HoMM game and I recall within minutes not liking it, deleting it and for the next 13 years avoiding all HoMM titles.GEEEEEEZZZZZ, what was I thinking!?!On a whim, I played Kings Bounty for the first time last Friday, "KB: Legend"...I loved it !And also was happy to find out that HoMM and KB are related.This got me thinking to give HoMM a 2nd chance, so I bought HoMM V and OMG I love it!I could not stop playing it!Although, I finished it, I still have Hammer of Fate to play.But, that could not stop me from wanting to try HoMM VI with its upgraded graphics.My initial hesitation on Steam to return to HoMM games was due to mixed reviews regarding the versions of HoMM that require the infamous "UPlay".But, being a techie I was determined to not let UPlay ruin my fun.Despite, not being able to play HoMM VI due to a UPlay error, that caused me to RAGE, I was able to get it to run with the help of our Steam forum members.As a result, I LOVE HoMM VI as well!1) Updated graphics2) Beautiful Sound Track3) Plays just like HoMM V, but with some changes that others complained about, but I do not mind.My only complaints thus far is that the voice acting is not as good as HoMM V, the Orc sounds downright cheesey. And of course the cinstant connection, Conflux and UPlay all adding to disk usage and duplicating Steam.if you never played a HoMM game before, let me tell you that the game design is very uniquer and fun and is being imitated by other games.For me, the allure is the way the game switches from strategic view to tactical view where the battles are fought.Loving it

content:
16, 2014
												I haven't yet played the game to completion, and I have picked it up for the sake of story completion, however if you played V and its expansions, prepare for disappointment...On the plus side, the game is visually pretty, like all HoMM games. The two hero option per faction has been restored, in the vein of III, which is great. The hero pathway has become more defined, but I can't help but feel it is more homogeneised now, and not as impressive as V's skill system. It provides more options for the player to choose whether to rely on might or magic, so you don't have oddities like a Warlock hero focusing on unit-oriented abilities, and can instead take a hero suited to this path. Sandro is also back!VI also brought in the Naga as a faction, who I find interesting.On the negative side, I feel the battle system is simplistic compared to V's. Most units have had their abilities stripped down, and V's awesome system of two upgrade options per unit (introduced in ToTE, IIRC) is gone. Many of the factions have had their unit makeup shaken up and a distinction between "core" and "elite" units, which has always existed, at least on an informal basis. Again, I feel V has it beaten on this aspect. The Sylvan and Academy didn't make it in. I've little love for Stronghold, which ToTE brought in, and their exclusion for this faction did little to appease me. The artwork and music of V was far grander and of a higher quality. All in all, it's slightly above average, and I'd give it a 6/10. I'm hoping VII will revert to the pathway carved out by V, which was an excellent attempt by Ubisoft at remaking this series to its own liking.

												I haven't yet played the game to completion, and I have picked it up for the sake of story completion, however if you played V and its expansions, prepare for disappointment...On the plus side, the game is visually pretty, like all HoMM games. The two hero option per faction has been restored, in the vein of III, which is great. The hero pathway has become more defined, but I can't help but feel it is more homogeneised now, and not as impressive as V's skill system. It provides more options for the player to choose whether to rely on might or magic, so you don't have oddities like a Warlock hero focusing on unit-oriented abilities, and can instead take a hero suited to this path. Sandro is also back!VI also brought in the Naga as a faction, who I find interesting.On the negative side, I feel the battle system is simplistic compared to V's. Most units have had their abilities stripped down, and V's awesome system of two upgrade options per unit (introduced in ToTE, IIRC) is gone. Many of the factions have had their unit makeup shaken up and a distinction between "core" and "elite" units, which has always existed, at least on an informal basis. Again, I feel V has it beaten on this aspect. The Sylvan and Academy didn't make it in. I've little love for Stronghold, which ToTE brought in, and their exclusion for this faction did little to appease me. The artwork and music of V was far grander and of a higher quality. All in all, it's slightly above average, and I'd give it a 6/10. I'm hoping VII will revert to the pathway carved out by V, which was an excellent attempt by Ubisoft at remaking this series to its own liking.

content:
, 2015
												As for the bugs and "OMG UPLAY DRM? UBI PLS DIE! OMGG CONFLUX NOOBS":A lot of complaining from a lot of people who are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ of. Give them no heed! Sure, it's tied with Uplay, but I like it. My game crashed the second I launched it. Googled uplay fix, they told me run uplay as admin not through steam, and it worked like a charm. I have no issues opening from steam directly anymore. If you want to play offline, you still can, but be careful that online/offline saves are not the same! If you start someway, stick with it! (though it has no consumption at all, so you might as well just use your 3G)As for the actual game:It's a great game, nice challenege, amazing graphics and HUD, pretty decent story (as far as video games go). I've played Heroes 5, and I can honestly say I liked this one more. Combar is more intuitive (no, the same creature can not act a billion times before your creature gets a turn), you can see info about every creature on the battlefield directly in a MUCH neater way than before (including what's affecting them and what that thing is) -- like I said, amazing HUD. Gameplay will get boring if you spend all your time waiting around for reinforcements! If you're playing it right, you should never be just waiting around.Magic is now a little less varied but more reliable (you pick what you want to learn and spend a 'skill point' rather than getting random ones in guilds) Same for skill level up. You have a build in mind? Go with it, don't hope you get the relavant skill when you level up.You can also convert towns (THANK YOU!), and summon creatures produced in multiple towns from the same town (no caravans, no 20 sub heroes shipping to the same main hero, just one place and go on with your life)Oh, and once more, the HUD is really really nice. It feels so fluid (unlike the VII one, sadly).No one online for multiplayer though, so don't buy it if that's your aim, but I'd definately recommend the game.

content:
, 2014
												Turn Based Strategy / Fantasy*Important BugsOverall 3 out of 5Complexity 3Graphics 3Immersive 3Inovative 3Game Pace 2This is a hard call between recommending or not, but at the end I think it is worth the money if you find a good discount.To make it easier I split the review in pro and against.Pro:This is very much like the original games, the ones that got very popular, with the addition of a relevant achievement system.There is this extra layer to the game where you create your heroes and give them the habilities, and as you play you do not only level in game but you also level your profile and acquire in game coins. This profile leveling allows you to expand the set of options for your heroe and the coins to acquire more habilities and other stuff for your set.It's interesting and fun developing your profile as if it as an in game character, and it gives extra game hours.The game itself is pretty much like the series, you have castles, armies, heroes and resources and you are in a row for conquering it all. The AI is decent enough, the creatures have a nice variation of habilities and magic is interesting although narrow.If you like the series, this is a good call. I personally didn't like the Heroes V, but this one I did. There's plenty hours of game in.Against:Ubisoft have been showing a tendency to shady business in recent developments, and this seems pretty much it.The games have loads of bugs that will probably never be fixed, it crashes, hangs, etc. also the Uplay is mandatory for this game, but there are bugs syncronising content making the loading a pain. Almost every time I open the game I have to wait for a long attempt to syncronise content with their server, eventually it fails for time out, and only then I can play.Another hint that Ubisoft do not really care much for fair play is that this is not a full version. You'll not find the Dungeon available, the only way to get this is to buy another fully independent game by a price way above a game pack. I'm also not sure if this is the only thing missing as I originally bought two game packs along with this because of a sale.Bugs and shady business aside there's one more annoyance, if you are a fan of multiplayer or stand alone, to take the most of the game you'll have to at least play one campaing with your favourite race, aside the introductory campaing. This is the only way to unlock some special items that will be attached to your account.The introdutoring campain is boring like hell but is "short", the race campain I can only tell about the Undead which is not bad.All in all, there's no other game like this. Falling Enchantress gets close to beat Heroes, but it misses some fundamental stuff. Others are too simple to be interesting for long... so in my opinion this is worth for the simple reason that there's no competitors for this game style, specially if you want to play with friends.If you are looking at games at random and not after this game style in specific, then stay away.

content:
1, 2014
												Ah... Heroes of Might and Magic 6. Now this game is amazing! Some may say that the new castle system is weird or bad or just completely messed up BUT this game is the step from the Heroes 4 and 5 back in teh way of heroes 3 which, as many say, was the best of them all. As many of us know by now, game requires much more than flashy graphics and cool animations to provide good and stimulating gameplay. Esspecially if it is a strategy game where you can just skip the combat (not that anyone who knows how to play does it) and you see the same animation over and over in a long campaign. And frankly I think Heroes 6 delivers. The new addition of Dynasty is interesting but considering the Ubisoft features and the Conflux with it along with all the facebook liking and skype shenanigans might have been a step too far towards the community. The thought is good but I'm pretty sure we all know how to switch on skype... I hope.  But concerning the game: Briliant! Esspecially if you want to play with more people online in a set up party. Great castles, very very well worked through passive abilities and active abilities in mosters and amazing heroes with teh new Blood and Tears system! Definitely worth the money

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2011
												I'm a little disappointed in Ubisoft for taking the Heroes series in kind of a weird direction. If you enjoyed the prior "Heroes" games for things like the cityscapes, faction details, and down-to-earth plots, you won't find all that much of those things in "Heroes VI". What you will find is over-the-top unit designs and a lot of the current trend to make the bad guys seem not so bad after all. The Inferno Faction has really suffered in that regard - it's not so much evil and demons as it is a bunch of misunderstood guys with horns.Gameplay, though - that's what's remained true to all the previous "Heroes" games, and the developers did a lot to expand on the options available to a Hero in terms of the skills and powers they can develop. The AI is a bit smarter, and the game can be very challenging if you don't stay on the ball in the early parts of missions. Some units are a lot more useful than others, and the factions have been homogenized a little bit, and there are only five...

I've been playing the games since Heroes III and Might and Magic VI (played Heroes II later) - I enjoy the references, the way things tie in and yes, the fact that some basic game mechanics have stayed at least similar/familiar.If you are a Heroes fan, this is still a must-have and a decent game!  If you're new to, it's still very entertaining turn-based strategy.

I've been playing the games since Heroes III and Might and Magic VI (played Heroes II later) - I enjoy the references, the way things tie in and yes, the fact that some basic game mechanics have stayed at least similar/familiar.If you are a Heroes fan, this is still a must-have and a decent game!  If you're new to, it's still very entertaining turn-based strategy.

content:
, 2015
												As for the bugs and "OMG UPLAY DRM? UBI PLS DIE! OMGG CONFLUX NOOBS":A lot of complaining from a lot of people who are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ of. Give them no heed! Sure, it's tied with Uplay, but I like it. My game crashed the second I launched it. Googled uplay fix, they told me run uplay as admin not through steam, and it worked like a charm. I have no issues opening from steam directly anymore. If you want to play offline, you still can, but be careful that online/offline saves are not the same! If you start someway, stick with it! (though it has no consumption at all, so you might as well just use your 3G)As for the actual game:It's a great game, nice challenege, amazing graphics and HUD, pretty decent story (as far as video games go). I've played Heroes 5, and I can honestly say I liked this one more. Combar is more intuitive (no, the same creature can not act a billion times before your creature gets a turn), you can see info about every creature on the battlefield directly in a MUCH neater way than before (including what's affecting them and what that thing is) -- like I said, amazing HUD. Gameplay will get boring if you spend all your time waiting around for reinforcements! If you're playing it right, you should never be just waiting around.Magic is now a little less varied but more reliable (you pick what you want to learn and spend a 'skill point' rather than getting random ones in guilds) Same for skill level up. You have a build in mind? Go with it, don't hope you get the relavant skill when you level up.You can also convert towns (THANK YOU!), and summon creatures produced in multiple towns from the same town (no caravans, no 20 sub heroes shipping to the same main hero, just one place and go on with your life)Oh, and once more, the HUD is really really nice. It feels so fluid (unlike the VII one, sadly).No one online for multiplayer though, so don't buy it if that's your aim, but I'd definately recommend the game.

content:
, 2014
												Turn Based Strategy / Fantasy*Important BugsOverall 3 out of 5Complexity 3Graphics 3Immersive 3Inovative 3Game Pace 2This is a hard call between recommending or not, but at the end I think it is worth the money if you find a good discount.To make it easier I split the review in pro and against.Pro:This is very much like the original games, the ones that got very popular, with the addition of a relevant achievement system.There is this extra layer to the game where you create your heroes and give them the habilities, and as you play you do not only level in game but you also level your profile and acquire in game coins. This profile leveling allows you to expand the set of options for your heroe and the coins to acquire more habilities and other stuff for your set.It's interesting and fun developing your profile as if it as an in game character, and it gives extra game hours.The game itself is pretty much like the series, you have castles, armies, heroes and resources and you are in a row for conquering it all. The AI is decent enough, the creatures have a nice variation of habilities and magic is interesting although narrow.If you like the series, this is a good call. I personally didn't like the Heroes V, but this one I did. There's plenty hours of game in.Against:Ubisoft have been showing a tendency to shady business in recent developments, and this seems pretty much it.The games have loads of bugs that will probably never be fixed, it crashes, hangs, etc. also the Uplay is mandatory for this game, but there are bugs syncronising content making the loading a pain. Almost every time I open the game I have to wait for a long attempt to syncronise content with their server, eventually it fails for time out, and only then I can play.Another hint that Ubisoft do not really care much for fair play is that this is not a full version. You'll not find the Dungeon available, the only way to get this is to buy another fully independent game by a price way above a game pack. I'm also not sure if this is the only thing missing as I originally bought two game packs along with this because of a sale.Bugs and shady business aside there's one more annoyance, if you are a fan of multiplayer or stand alone, to take the most of the game you'll have to at least play one campaing with your favourite race, aside the introductory campaing. This is the only way to unlock some special items that will be attached to your account.The introdutoring campain is boring like hell but is "short", the race campain I can only tell about the Undead which is not bad.All in all, there's no other game like this. Falling Enchantress gets close to beat Heroes, but it misses some fundamental stuff. Others are too simple to be interesting for long... so in my opinion this is worth for the simple reason that there's no competitors for this game style, specially if you want to play with friends.If you are looking at games at random and not after this game style in specific, then stay away.

Great castles, very very well worked through passive abilities and active abilities in mosters and amazing heroes with teh new Blood and Tears system! Definitely worth the money

content:
ry 6, 2016
												I'll be straightforward.I don't have a problem with the ubi launcher. It's a fail, but it does the job done. When it works.I don't have a problem with the dumped down resources. Although i prefer the old system, i can live with it.I don't have a problem with difficulty in general. Sometimes it can get rediculous, but you can also change it to easy.Where i do have the problem though, is with the games core mechanic that increases enemies army size every week like the players. It may look nice on paper and you can dump it down a little through difficult settings, but if you take your time (like me) wandering around the beautiful crafted map, or sometimes just killing every army you encounter, you'll hit sooner or later an overpowered enemy wall that you cannot cross.This is by the far the worse thing in the game in my opinion. It forces you to play fast and precise, otherwise you may end up in a really tight situation. Why? Why in earth can't i define my own game pace? It makes no sense. And if they liked that mechanism so much, why don't they just put a slider or something so the players can adjust in a precise way the amount of reinforcements enemies can get? Bad design choice.Apart of this, the game is nice with all it's problems. And it has lots, just read the following reviews. But it's also fun, has gorgeous graphics and a beautiful designed enviroment. Oh and the animations, are one of the best i've seen, kudos to the animation team/studio.It's a good game, full of bad design choices. A  5/10  from a series veteran.A solid  7/10  for the newcomers or the ones who simply don't care.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
y 28, 2016
												I love the M&M series and have been playing it since HOMM 2 (I later went and purchased the bundle pack of HOMM 2 so I could experience HOMM 1). This game brings alot of changes to the series and I personally like the fresh take on the series. Major changes include, the new leveling system, spell system, blood and tears system, and dynasty system.The leveling system is different in this entry in that you actually get to choose the path and perks of your hero as they level. While this gets rid of a bit of the luck side of things when leveling it adds a strategy layer to picking your perks and leveling your hero. For those new to the series, in older games when your hero leveled you got to pick from a selection of randomly generated perks and skills. Sometimes you got the ones you wanted... sometimes you didnt. I can see how some loyal heroes fans would be upset about this major change but I personally enjoyed it. I felt like I had far more control over the outcome of my hero.The spell system in this entry has been overhauled as well. In previous games you would have schools of magic and spells that fell under those schools. You'd build mage guilds in your towns and get a random selection of spells from different schools of magic. Certain Factions were more likely to get specific magic types. In this game schools of magic are only available to certain factions. Spells and perks that you would get from a school of magic are part of the leveling system. When you level up you can pick a spell, a skill, or a perk. You no longer learn spells from mage guilds and shrines. I can understand how this draws away from classic heroes and can upset some devout fans but I believe the outcome is better. You can learn your spells on the fly (without having to go back to town everytime you buy a new level in the mage guild), Certain high level spells are restricted to level requirements (no level 5 guy smashing your team with death ripple), and you can pick between a weaker but wider range of spells or focus in a specific school and make those spells stronger. Again I believe it adds an extra layer of strategy and gets rid of some of the luck.the Blood and Tears System is an entirely new addition to the heroes franchise. The system rewards consistant gameplay style by giving you points towards your style. Blood being ruthless and tears being compasionate. You gain points for actions such as persuing and slaughtering lesser creatures (blood), or allowing them to flee (tears). When you get enough points your hero gains a special perk garnered to that gameplay style. It's an interesting feature and certainly brings something to the table. I found myself many a time slaughtering weak armies just for the blood points when i'd normally let them flee just to save combat time.The Dynasty system is a new addition as well. This particular addition came with some powerful perks at the cost of a miriad of major drawbacks. Perks include weapons with their own leveling system that can be passed from hero to hero and small perks that could give a starting advantage to new games. The DRM system forces you to be online in order to take advantage of the perks you can gain through dynasty. It can be relatively annoying if your playing games and you are disconnected. All in all I enjoyed the game and got my moneys worth out of it. While I understand that the vast majority of the negative reviews are for bugs or the DRM system the game itself is worth playing and is IMO the best HOMM available on steam. That being said HOMM 3 (and its expansions) is probably still my favorite entry in the series and is available on GOG.

												1) This game is by Ubisoft 2) It requires Uplay (third party gaming app) to play.     If you are still not convinced not to buy it...3) The launcher now crashes on startup (and is generally buggy), after I took a long time away from playing it.    Why did I stop playing it? Because...4) The game mechanic where you have to mindlessly click through turns just to get a big enough army to defeat the final castle in missions is still very much applicable. Click, click, click...5) Did I mention you can't access your saved games if you are offline, for whatever reason? You actually have to make offline saved games, which are separate from the normal saved games.I played through all campaigns of M&M 5, and all add-ons (a final battle in one of those was bugged, where you just kept fighting the battle over and over). So I've played a fair share. It's a pity about the problems with this one.6) Oh, and with reference to M&M 5. You remember those lovely cities with inspiring music, that were arguably the most enjoyable/well-done features in the game? Well, no longer. They've actually been downgraded.Despite all this, I would actually like to play the game some more. Sadly, point 3 rears it's ugly head.

												I dont recommend this game. ive played heroes of might and magic 3 and 4, but this game doesnt compare.its mostly because of the bugs in the game. you cant properly play multiplayer because you constantly lose connection eventhough it doesnt have anything to do with your actual internet connection. btw this only happens when i try to play with 2 or more of my friends so it ususally works if you play with just 1 friend and hot seat does work. ive also tried this game on lan with more that 3 people and that also wasnt playable.another problem of the game is that you need a connection with conflux (ubisoft) to play online and conflux usually has problems. ive read a lot of forum messages that conflux doesnt work and it seems like ubisoft is just ignoring all the bugs that are in the game and or connected to conflux. if conflux does work it usually takes 15 seconds to connect for some it takes even longer.if you want to buy this game to play this with friends i would recommend another game. it was the main reason for me to buy this games as i dont enjoy this type of games in single player modes.
